newLineChart
The function is used to create a line chart.
To learn about the stages of creating a chart, see the
Universal graph dashboard
article.
Syntax
newLineChart
( )
There are no parameters for the function.
Working with the function involves filling
fields of the HighChart class instance
.
Note
Adding a function to the algorithm code is done from the "Charts" section of the algorithm editor toolbar.
When calling the finction, it will insert the algorithm code template, which should be edited as part of the task.
Algorithm template code to build a line chart:
def
chart :
= newLineChart()
chart.
title :
=
"Line Chart Title"
//chart.setTitleStyle(Default formatting style for the universal chart title)
chart.
subTitle :
=
"Line Chart Subtitle"
//chart.setSubTitleStyle(Default formatting style for the universal chart subtitle)
chart.xAxis.
title :
=
"X-axis title"
chart.yAxis.
title :
=
"Y-axis title"
chart.setPalette(
"STANDARD_PALETTE"
)
chart.setCyclicalPalette(
true
)
def
serie :
= newChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Serie 1"
def
objId :
=
1
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
80
).setX(
-76.5
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
70
).setX(
-55.7
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
60
).setX(
-27.7
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
50
).setX(
-2.5
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
40
).setX(
-22.1
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
30
).setX(
-46.5
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
20
).setX(
-56.5
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
10
).setX(
-50
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
0
).setX(
15
).setId(objId))
/*objId is an optional parameter: use it for drill-down charts.
objId should contain object id.
You can use the add function without objId parameter instead of the addWithId function if you don't need this parameter
*/
chart.series.add(serie)
serie :
= newChartSerie()
serie.
name :
=
"Serie 2"
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
80
).setX(
-70.5
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
70
).setX(
-50.7
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
60
).setX(
-23.7
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
50
).setX(
-1
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
40
).setX(
-17
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
30
).setX(
-30
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
20
).setX(
-38
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
10
).setX(
-31
).setId(objId))
serie.values.add(newChartValue(
0
).setX(
10
).setId(objId))
serie.marker.
symbol :
=
"diamond"
serie.marker.
radius :
=
3.5
serie.marker.
lineWidth :
=
1
serie.marker.
lineColor :
=
"rgb(255, 145, 0)"
serie.marker.
fillColor :
=
"rgb(255, 145, 0)"
chart.series.add(serie)
chart.legend.
enabled :
=
true
chart
groovy
Copied!
When calling the function, the code template includes methods for setting the chart title and subtitle styles, with reference to the name of the directory object used by default.
To keep the code functional, these lines are commented out in the article.
When configuring the title/subtitle style, use the
dict
function to select a type instance that is a child of the "Formatting and tooltip styles" [STYLES_DICTIONARY] type, for example,
"Main formatting style"
.
For more information about the functions and methods used to create charts, see the article
"Universal chart configuration"
.
When creating a line chart, it is assumed that there are axes that have the following parameters:
chart.xAxis.title – name of the X-axis;
chart.yAxis.title – name of the Y -axis.
Which are set in the following form:
chart.xAxis.title := "X-axis value"
chart.yAxis.title := "Y-axis value"
The preferred scale of the axes is calculated automatically.
Use example
It is required to build a chart of two functions: y(x) = 10*sin(x/3) and y(x) = 6*sin(x*2)*cos(x/2).
This task can be done using the following algorithm:
// Create a line chart
def
chart :
= newLineChart()
// Add title and subtitle to the chart
chart.
title :
=
"Line Chart"
chart.
subTitle :
=
"Based on trigonometric expressions"
// Y-axis title
chart.yAxis.
title :
=
"Y-axis Value"
// Create series for the first chart
def
s1 :
= newChartSerie()
// Name for the first series
s1.
name :
=
"Expression with Sine"
// Color of the first series
s1.
color :
=
"#7CB5EC"
// Create series for the second chart
def
s2 :
= newChartSerie()
// Name for the second series
s2.
name :
=
"Combination of Functions"
// Color of the second series
s2.
color :
=
"#FF0000"
// Marker shape for the second series
s2.marker.
symbol :
=
"diamond"
// Marker radius for the second series
s2.marker.
radius :
=
6
// Marker border width for the second series
s2.marker.
lineWidth :
=
1
// Marker border color for the second series
s2.marker.
lineColor :
=
"rgb(255, 145, 0)"
// Marker fill color for the second series
s2.marker.
fillColor :
=
"#B6FF50"
// Add data sets (series)
for
(
def
i :
=
1
; i <
20
;
i :
= i+
1
) {
s1.values.add(round(
10
*Math.sin(i/
3
),
0
))
s2.values.add(round(
6
*Math.sin(i*
2
)*Math.cos(i/
2
),
2
))
}
// Add series to the chart
chart.series.add(s1)
chart.series.add(s2)
// Return the chart
chart
groovy
Copied!
To write the algorithm, the
newLineChart
function is used, and the code template has been adjusted as part of the task.
To optimize the code, the addition of the data set is implemented using a loop with the
for
function.
When using the algorithm with the
Universal Graph Dashboard
data source, a line chart of the following type will be generated:
When hovering the cursor over a point of one chart, a tooltip appears, and the second chart is dimmed:
If needed, the user can hide the markers, change their style, and add labels. For more details, see
"Configuring the Universal Graph"
.
